awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Eric Larson is "Algebraic Geometry." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University and the sponsoring scientist is Ravi Vakil.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main outcomes of this grant was significant progress on the interpolation problem for curves, one of the oldest problems in mathematics whose study goes back over two millennia to the time of Euclid. That is, given a type of curve, we ask through how many points such a curve can be passed. For example, one can draw a line through any 2 points in the plane, but given 3 points, it is usually impossible to draw a line through them; thus, we say that lines interpolate through 2 points. Similarly, circles interpolate through 3 points in the plane. In higher-dimensional space, however, this problem becomes more delicate. During the initial part of this grant, the PI published four papers solving special cases of the interpolation problem. Near the end, in a joint preprint with Vogt, the PI extended these results to cover all types of "Brill--Noether" curves, thereby obtaining the first comprehensive results.

The interpolation problem also has striking applications to the study of other geometric problems about curves. One such application is to the Maximal Rank Conjecture, a longstanding problem which predicts the relationship between two different ways of describing curves:


(1) Via Parametric equations, i.e., equations that tell you how to generate all the points on a curve. For example, a circle can be described parametrically as (x, y) = (cos(t), sin(t)).

(2) Via Cartesian equations, i.e., equations that tell you whether or not a given point lies on a curve. For example, a circle can be described in Cartesian equations as the set of points (x, y) with x^2 + y^2 = 1.

In a sequence of four papers --- one of which was published with the support of this grant, two of which were accepted for publication, and the final of which remains under review --- the PI settled this conjecture.

The PI also obtained several results describing what sorts of algebraic curves can exist. The first of these papers, published with the support of this grant, concerns "intersection theory", that is, in what ways different sorts of conditions one might seek to impose on algebraic curves can be simultaneously satisfied. This paper gave the first complete description of this intersection theory in the simplest case (for curves of genus 2). The second of these papers concerns the problem of how the presence of a map from a curve to some space affects the possible maps from that curve to other spaces. Namely, in a joint preprint with H. Larson and Vogt, the PI resolved this question when the first of these spaces is a line.

Finally, in joint work with Coskun and Vogt, the PI studied several natural vector bundles attached to curves that reflect important aspects of their geometry. Roughly speaking, a vector bundle is a family of spaces that can twist as we move along the curve; for example, the famous Mobius strip is a vector bundle on the circle. A key property of vector bundles is their stability, which reflects whether this twisting happens primarily in a small piece of the vector bundle, or is spread out evenly. This grant supported the publication of one paper on this topic for curves in 3-dimensional space, as well as two preprints on this topic for certain other types of curves.

The PI also organized several activities for early-career researchers and students, including:

(1) The AGNES Summer Workshop in Algebraic Geometry (joint with D. Abramovich, M. Chan, B. Hassett, and I. Vogt).

(2) A preparation seminar for the Putnam competition, to teach undergraduate students problem-solving skills.
